summary.topic: i want to share my journey on asking for help and how it improved my life
summary.summary: just wanted to share my journey on how i asked for help and how it improved my life. setting a clear goal made all the difference.

summary.topic: in 2014, i finished high school and didn't want to go to college but graduated in 2018 due to parental pressure
summary.summary: in 2014, i finished high school and often posted on snapchat about balancing a million-dollar idea with chem homework. i didn't want to go to college because i was already making money selling shirts online. however, by 2018, i graduated college and moved to san francisco with my family.

summary.topic: i've always been very solo and never asked anyone for help until it became necessary
summary.summary: i graduated college mainly due to my parents' insistence, freeing me from the expectations of my pakistani family. despite finding college somewhat useless, i managed to build a product that gained 500k users in its first year and 234,000 users as of 2023. i also worked on ai projects and self-driving cars, making college somewhat worthwhile.

summary.topic: upon finishing college, i felt alone and stagnated, not knowing what to do next
summary.summary: graduated college in 2018 feeling stagnated and alone, unsure of my next steps. i struggled with my own weaknesses and had no one to ask for help. up to that point, i had always worked solo, which made it hard to reach out.

summary.topic: in 2018, i was clueless about how to fix my problems and how to ask for help
summary.summary: realized this and started writing a blog. it's been a game changer for my productivity and focus. turns out, putting thoughts into words helps me process and prioritize like never before.

summary.topic: i started writing a weekly newsletter in 2018 to share my journey and possibly get help
summary.summary: started the newsletter out of a sense of hopelessness and to document weekly activities. didn't know much about social media but used Snapchat and email to share updates. maintained hyper consistency, writing every week for nearly four years. the newsletter began in november 2018, initially focusing on a project called build space, designed to help people learn programming by combining their interests with something they enjoy.

summary.topic: the initial readers of my newsletter were mainly close family and friends
summary.summary: five six seven eight nine there's alec, my dad, and shareif, who you see walking around a lot. these are the only people i felt would care about what i was working on. so, i started talking about stuff, like the anime death note, in my email newsletter.

summary.topic: over time, more people started replying to my newsletter, offering advice and support
summary.summary: i was curious about a death note plot hole—what if someone doesn't have a name? it turns out such a person gets assigned a name after 780 days by a shinigami. in 2018, i had an idea to create a program using machine learning to scan for common coding mistakes, and i was sharing ideas like this and "kanga 2." initially, no one responded to my newsletters except my supportive dad, but eventually, more people like alec and david arnetto from google started engaging with my work.

summary.topic: sean puri, a known personality, replied to my newsletter with positive and supportive messages
summary.summary: so, i met this guy through my newsletter and we hit it off over lunch in new york. fast forward a year, sean puri, an internet celebrity, starts replying to my newsletter with advice and roasting my ideas. our email exchanges evolved into deep conversations and even contemplating starting a company together, showing the importance of nurturing relationships that can help you grow.

summary.topic: sean even offered to fund my ideas and guide me, which made me realize the importance of seeking help
summary.summary: he offered to work with me every week on the idea and laid out how we'd split ownership. i was amazed and realized i shouldn't navigate the world alone. sean's replies were a weekly blessing.

summary.topic: sean's weekly replies became a significant motivation for me to keep writing
summary.summary: i kept making the newsletter mainly because there was a 25% chance shawn would find it interesting and give valuable feedback. this small possibility was enough motivation, even though it took me four hours a week. shawn's unexpected help was invaluable.

summary.topic: sean's guidance helped with things i didn't know i needed help with
summary.summary: i'm not asking shawn questions directly; instead, i tell him my story, and he reflects with suggestions or considerations. this approach is more helpful because i didn’t know the questions to ask since i’m new to the startup world. shawn's experience helped me navigate this unfamiliar territory.

summary.topic: in 30 emails and 10-20 phone calls, sean changed my life trajectory
summary.summary: in 30 emails and 10 phone calls, this man changed my life even though we'd never met in person at the time. it's mind-blowing how a few interactions can have such an impact. i'm sharing this because most people suck at asking for help, and everyone needs help—even if things seem to be going great, you will eventually stagnate and need support.

summary.topic: understanding stagnation and how seeking help can move you past it is crucial
summary.summary: big spikes followed by flat periods are more realistic as they show stagnation. you might be flat for months, figure something out, then go flat again, backslide, and then make progress again. these transitions are tough to navigate alone and require proactive effort.

summary.topic: you always need help, even if you don't realize it, to avoid stagnation
summary.summary: you're going to stay stuck if you don't push past stagnation. it's very hard to break out on your own; you need people ahead of you in your specific field to guide you. surround yourself with supportive friends but also seek out mentors who can help you level up.

summary.topic: look for people ahead of you who can guide you in specific domains
summary.summary: there's always that one person who helps you break through stagnation and figure out your next step, whether it’s a parent, a friend, or a mentor. asking for help can look like a classic mentor-mentee relationship, similar to steve jobs and mike marula.

summary.topic: establishing strong mentor-mentee relationships can significantly push your progress
summary.summary: steve jobs's mentor gave him money to start his company, similar to how skrillex helped porter robinson or dr. dre helped eminem. these mentor-mentee relationships often turn into lasting partnerships, like key and peele in comedy or disney and the animator ub iwerks. mentors help elevate talent, leading to enduring collaborations.

summary.topic: mentors help turn small improvements into significant milestones in your journey
summary.summary: that guy was brilliant at animation, much like a top-notch developer who can outshine you. back in the day, walt disney knew he wasn't the best at animation, so he partnered with someone exceptional to help him out. it was more of a partnership.

summary.topic: building long-term relationships with people ahead of you prevents stagnation
summary.summary: miyazaki was great at making movies but terrible at marketing them, so he teamed up with suzuki for that. this highlights the importance of asking for help. even if the help looks small, like showing someone an instagram post, it's a start. we should aim to ask for help directly and thoughtfully to push our work forward and not tackle everything solo.

summary.topic: ask for help in a direct and specific manner, focusing on small things you need to improve
summary.summary: take something small you want to get good at and find someone two to three steps ahead of you in that area. make a direct ask for help; they don't need to be experts, just ahead of you. finding someone is often just a DM away—reach out, even if it's through unconventional channels like lesser-used social media accounts.

summary.topic: track your journey and let others see your consistent efforts
summary.summary: focus on reaching out directly to individuals slightly ahead of you in a specific aspect of your work. dig into their backgrounds to find a connection point for your message. also, consider opening yourself up to let others track your journey and help you along the way.

summary.topic: creating content like newsletters or vlogs gives people opportunities to help you
summary.summary: if you want help, you need to make it obvious that you need it. share your needs clearly so people can offer assistance. using methods like newsletters or concise one-page docs has worked for me, and others have found success with their approaches like video updates. the key is to provide an easy way for people to understand how they can help you.

summary.topic: don't be afraid to communicate your struggles and ask for feedback
summary.summary: nishu sends updates to stan through vlogs, even if stan sometimes doesn't reply. another friend updates me with monthly voice notes, and i don't feel pressured to respond, but i appreciate the updates. sharing struggles is tough, but it's worthwhile because most people don't care or judge as much as we think they do. it's about being genuine and giving others a chance to connect with you over what's real, rather than just your victories.

summary.topic: always follow up with results or updates when you get help from someone
summary.summary: if you ask for help, follow up with the results quickly. showing feedback to the person who helped you makes them more invested in your progress. if you don't, they're less likely to help you again because it feels like a waste of time. make your problems easy to understand, don't drain the helper's energy, and always show the impact of their help to keep them engaged.

summary.topic: don't think of asking for help as a one-off event; see it as a long-term relationship
summary.summary: helping others in a long-term, consistent manner feels great and often turns into friendships. asking for help shouldn't be a one-time request but rather a continuous relationship. avoid making one-off requests because they can be exhausting; keep the conversation going and build a meaningful connection.

summary.topic: you won't annoy someone with updates; people like to see the results of their advice
summary.summary: never annoy someone with results, they appreciate the effort more than the outcome. speaking of effort, i wrote a successful blog post in 2018 that caught the attention of Furon from founder Inc, who has significantly impacted my life. a mutual connection led to a casual thank-you message, which turned into a meeting with Furon.

summary.topic: i developed a strong relationship with furqan, who became a key advisor and supporter
summary.summary: he offers me dinner at his office with his chef cooking for us, which was awesome. we kept talking every week, and it turned into almost three years of weekly chats. i was relentless in asking for things, assuming he'd tell me if it was annoying.

summary.topic: we maintained a weekly chat for three years, and i shared everything with furqan, including emotional struggles
summary.summary: wednesday nights, fron would call me, we'd screen share, and he’d critique my work with candid feedback and new ideas. every week was fun, as he enjoyed watching me explore new concepts, and we kept each other motivated. i shared everything with him, from my personal struggles to professional updates, and he consistently guided me like a partner.

summary.topic: no one seeks to help you initially; the opportunity to help must be created
summary.summary: working pretty solo in my life, i finally had someone to share wins with, like getting into yc in 2020. my family didn't care or understand, but fon cared, and that was fun. i've learned no one actually wants to help you, and those who do often come off weird, so maybe steer clear of self-proclaimed mentors.

summary.topic: asking for help shouldn't be a solo mission; always seek out people who can guide you
summary.summary: yeah, no one seeks to help you, it just kind of happens. over time, you become good friends with those who help, like how forgan became more of a brother than a mentor. this journey doesn't need to be solo; open up and ask for help in the ways described.
